DOCNAME: CASE OF APEH ULDOZOTTEINEK SZÖVETSEGE AND OTHERS v. HUNGARY
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 6-1;Non-pecuniary damage - finding of violation sufficient
TEXT: CARDINAL . APEH Üldözötteinek Szövetsége ( Alliance of ORG 's Persecutees ) is an unregistered association with its head office in GPE . ORG is the commonly used abbreviation for ORG ( Adó- és FAC – “ ORG ” ) .

PERSON , born in DATE and residing in GPE , GPE , is a manager and a vice - president of the applicant association . PERSON , born in DATE and residing in GPE , is a lawyer and a vice - president of the applicant association . Mr PERSON , born in DATE and residing in GPE , is a free - lance writer and the president of the applicant association .

CARDINAL . In DATE several private persons , among others PERSON , Mr PERSON and Mr PERSON , founded the applicant association . Its articles of association , dated DATE , state that the purpose of the association is , in particular , to promote the general interests of NORP taxpayers .

CARDINAL . On DATE the President of ORG , having learnt about the founding of the applicant association from the press , complained to the GPE public prosecutor and the President of ORG that the choice of name was defamatory for ORG . He requested that particular attention be paid to the proceedings concerning the association 's registration and that his office have access to the documents relating to the proceedings . These letters of the President of ORG reached the addressees on DATE , but were not communicated to the applicants in the subsequent non - contentious proceedings aiming at the applicant association 's registration .
CARDINAL . On DATE Mr PERSON requested ORG to register the applicant association .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG returned the request for registration , ordering that ORG 's approval for the use of its name be obtained , that the expression “ persecutees ” in the applicant association 's name be altered to a neutral term and that provisions regulating the method of voting within the applicant association 's bodies be added to its articles of association .
ORG obtained a copy of this order from ORG before it was served on the applicants and , in a television programme on DATE , its spokesman presented it .

CARDINAL . By a letter dated DATE the public prosecutor 's office intervened in the registration proceedings under LAW no . DATE on the Code of Civil Procedure ( “ the Code of Civil Procedure ” ) . ORG received this letter on DATE . The applicants were not notified of this intervention .

CARDINAL . Following some delays in the service of the order of DATE , the applicants submitted their reply to ORG on CARDINAL DATE . They refused to obtain ORG 's approval for the use of its name or to alter the impugned expression . Moreover , they stated that the information on the method of voting by the applicant association 's bodies was available from their original submissions requesting the registration .

Simultaneously , the applicants challenged the judge in charge of the case , as well as the entire ORG , for bias on the ground that , inter alia , they had not been informed about the intervention by the public prosecutor 's office in the registration proceedings .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicants ' challenge for bias . ORG found that ORG procedure had been in compliance with the relevant legal provisions and there was nothing to support the applicants ' allegations as to any bias on the part of ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE the public prosecutor 's office proposed to ORG that the applicant association 's request for registration be rejected , as the association had not met the requirements in the court order of DATE . This submission was received by ORG on CARDINAL DATE and was ordered to be sent to the applicants on DATE .

CARDINAL . In their submissions dated DATE , but filed with ORG only on DATE , the applicants confirmed that they had meanwhile adopted an amendment to the articles of association , reflecting ORG requirements as to the voting methods . Moreover , they argued that the requirement that they seek ORG 's approval for the use of its name was legally “ absurd ” .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG rejected the applicant association 's request for registration . It observed that the applicants had not obtained ORG 's approval for the use of its name . In this respect , ORG relied on section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of PERSON no . DATE on freedom of association ( “ the Associations Act DATE ” ) , according to which the name of an association should not give the impression that the association in question carries on its activities in a manner linked to those of another legal person , unless approved by the latter . Moreover , it held that the expression “ persecutees ” was defamatory for ORG as a ORG organ and was contrary to the standards of naming an association , as laid down by ORG in its ORG Legal Opinion no . CARDINAL . Finally , ORG found that the applicant association had only partly met the requirements as to the method of voting by its bodies .
CARDINAL . The applicants appealed to ORG . Simultaneously , they complained about the dismissal of their challenge for bias .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Attorney - ORG intervened in the appeal proceedings and proposed that ORG uphold the refusal of the request for registration . The applicants did not receive a copy of these submissions .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant association 's appeal . In addition to the reasons given by ORG , it held that the applicant association 's name did not correspond to its objectives , namely to reform the NORP taxation system , and that it could therefore not be registered under that name . The decision did not deal with the applicants ' complaint about the dismissal of their challenge for bias .
The applicants lodged a petition for review by ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE the Attorney - ORG requested that ORG uphold the second - instance decision .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the petition for review . The decision was served on the applicants on DATE .

The review bench of ORG held that the association 's intended name was contrary to LAW guaranteeing the right to bear a name . It held this provision to imply that a legal person 's name should not give the false impression that its activity was linked to that of another legal person , namely , to that of ORG in the instant case . It also found that the unauthorised use of ORG 's name contravened LAW , according to which it was a breach of the right to bear a name if anyone used , without authorisation , a name identical with or similar to another person 's name . Moreover , it considered that the expression “ persecutees ” , used in association with ORG 's name , was contrary to LAW protecting one 's good reputation .

Furthermore , ORG held that any procedural shortcomings committed by the lower courts , in particular those concerning the handling of the submissions of ORG and of the public prosecutor 's office , had not influenced the courts ' decisions on the merits of the case . It also stated that , throughout the proceedings , the applicants had been in a position to exercise their rights effectively and , in the course of the second - instance and the review proceedings , they could have made any comments which they had not been able to advance previously .
Finally , ORG pointed out that the applicants ' complaint about the dismissal of their challenge for bias could not be examined in review proceedings .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the Associations Act DATE provides that freedom of association is a fundamental freedom for everyone . It guarantees that everyone shall have the right to form , together with other persons , organisations and communities or to participate in the activities of such associations .
Section CARDINAL ) provides that the exercise of the right to freedom of association may not violate the rights and freedoms of others .
Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) prohibits the founding of associations primarily for economic or business purposes .

According to section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) , as in force when the applicant association 's request for registration was examined , subsequent to the founding of an association , its registration must be requested before a court . Registration must not be denied unless the founders have failed to comply with the conditions specified in the LAW ; associations acquire legal capacity through registration .

Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) provides that the name and the objectives of an association must not create the impression that the activity it carries on is linked to the activity of another legal person , unless consent thereto is given by that legal person .

According to section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) , the courts must decide on requests for registration in non - contentious proceedings ; such requests must be given priority . The courts ' decisions must also be served on the public prosecutor 's office .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of Government Decree no . PERSON ( DATE ) provides that in non - contentious proceedings the provisions of LAW must be applied , mutatis mutandis , unless the legal provisions governing certain non - contentious proceedings provide otherwise or the non - contentious nature of the proceedings excludes that .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § § DATE of PERSON no . CARDINAL of DATE on LAW provide that everyone shall have the right to bear a name ; it is a violation of this right if anyone unlawfully uses a name identical with or similar to the name of another person .

According to LAW , protection of personality rights includes protection of the right to a good reputation ; making or disseminating false or defamatory allegations against other persons or portraying real facts in a false way is deemed to be an infringement of the right to a good reputation .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the Code of Civil Procedure , as in force in the relevant period , provides that , to ensure compliance with the law , the public prosecutor may intervene in civil proceedings at any stage .

According to LAW , when intervening in civil proceedings , the public prosecutor enjoys all the procedural rights which the parties enjoy , save the rights to negotiate settlements , to waive rights or to acknowledge rights .

CARDINAL . An extract from ORG Legal Opinion no . CARDINAL reads as follows : “ Before a decision is taken on the registration of an association , it must be examined whether the association 's choice of name meets the requirements of the exclusivity , genuineness and correctness of names . ”
